statement.p: One measure of ductility is area reduction. This is the percent decrease of area after pulling a sample piece of metal. The formula is \displaystyle{R}=\frac{{{A}-{B}}}{{A}}\times{100} where A and B are the areas before and after the pull.

Guido uses callipers to measure the diameters and calculates \displaystyle{A}=\pi\frac{{\left({d}_{{A}}\right)}^{{2}}}{{4}} and \displaystyle{B}=\pi\frac{{\left({d}_{{B}}\right)}^{{2}}}{{4}}, where \displaystyle{d}_{{A}} and \displaystyle{d}_{{B}} are the diameters as shown above, then calculates the area reduction. Wolfgang calculates the area reduction using solely the diameters (effectively \displaystyle{A}={d}_{{A}} and \displaystyle{B}={d}_{{B}}).
Do they end up with the same result?
